Sex(tus) Iu[lius Sex(ti) f(ilius)] / Ani(ensi) Silva[nus Foro Iulii] / summus c[urat(or) c(ivium) R(omanorum) prov(inciae) Dalm(atiae)] / suffragio [eorum factus vet(eranus?)] / leg(ionis) VII C(laudiae) P(iae) F(idelis) aed[ilis col(oniae) Claudiae Aequi ab] / ordine primus [post col(oniam) ded(uctam) creatus] / IIIIvir i(ure) d(icundo) pont(ifex) [in col(onia?) Salona(?) ---] / in ag[ro] p(edes) [---] / h(oc) s(epulcrum) h(eredem) [n(on) s(equetur)]
column19: Inscription framentary. It is not commemorating a Legio VII soldier, but one (a group) is mentioned. It commeorates S Julius Silvanus becoming first Aedile of colony at Aequum, a position which he seems to have been voted into by Legio VII veterans. Moreover, he is referred to as a quatrovir with judicial authority and pontifex powers.

column16: Maybe 6 to 42 if one does not accept the existence of a cpf title
column19: Fragmentary, no explicit mention of Legio VII extant, but possibility of CPF. This plus its location near Tilurium means it likley belonged to a member of Legio VII. It was found reused in Vojnić. It could technically also be ascribed to Legio XI, but VII more likley of the two on account of location. Inv. No. A 1982

column9: T(itus) Curtiacus / T(iti) f(ilius) Lem(onia) Bon(onia) / vet(eranus) leg(ionis) VII C(laudiae) P(iae) F(idelis) / h(ic) s(itus) e(st) t(estamento) f(ieri) i(ussit)
column18: Basilica of Santa Maria in Porto
column19: EDH and Trismegistos record that it is now held in this Basilica (in its art museum?), but was inscribed in Dalmatia (CIL). For the former reason, the EDCS seems to record (incorrectly) that it was found in Ravenna (where the Basilica is). Unsure of why or how it arrived in Ravenna after it was recorded in the CIL. Perhaps moved across for the re-opening of the Church in 1900, as part of its restoration in 1944, or its promotion to 'Basilica' in 1960. It has also has had an art Gallery since 1972. Wikipedia, 2019: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santa_Maria_in_Porto_Basilica. Accessed: 26/06/2020

column19: Inv. No. AMS-39605. Bust is split in half(or even thirds) only right-most piece survives. CPF is reconstructed off of the drawings in the CIL and Maršić which seem to indicate that the whole inscriptions was once visible. However, the stela is missing from the head of the child in the portrait and up, therefore no obervation can be made about the existence of 'weapons'.

column19: Inv. No. MCK-B-1373. Note, it does have a 'military medal' on its bottom third. It also has a second epitaph in the middle with a poem. Sanader, Demicheli, Bradač 2013 discuss this stelae when arguing a poet lived at the military camp of Tilurium. They provide a good english translation too. The first two lines are elegiac couplet, then there is a third hexameter with an extra line.

column5: In three fragments, second peice found in 1878, third from 1903. Bulić 1903a was the first to combine them all to form one monument

column19: Inv. No. A 1984. No explicit mention of Legio VII, but it was at tilurium, and the individual is possibly from the same (eastern) tribe as MonumentID 31 (CIL, 3, 9734), and it is military in nature. Tončinić 2011, 79

column9: M(arcus) Percenni[us---] / Voltinia Ph[ilippis] / [--- l]eg(ionis) [
column19: Inv. No. A 2458. Not explicitly Legio VII, but ascribed to it by Hofmann, Betz, Wilkes and Fadić on account of find site and the reconstructed voting tribe and location at Phillipi (where other legio VII people are attested to be from). Could be an eques, from Legio VII or any other legio/cohors/ala attseted to at the site.

column9: Q(uinto) Petro/nio Vale/nti militiav(it) / leg(ione) VII G[=C](laudia) P(ia) F(ideli) / h(ic) s(itus) e(st)
column19: Tončinić 2011. The 'G' has been interpreted by Betz as a 'C' (typological error). Unit used to be attributed to Legio VII Gemina, which was once located in Pannonia. Legio VII CPF more likely however.

column9: Pinaria C(ai) lib(erta) / [--- ---] / patrono suo / C(aio) Pinario Scarpo / [ve]t(erano) leg(ionis) VII et filio / [
column19: Inv. No. A 3164. Found in Ćabo, Salona, probablz in Situ in Salona's North Necropolis near the Manstirine. Only the epitaph has survived, so no comments can be made about design/style.

column5: Pre 1928: Found during the excavations of Brønsted published in 1928
column9: Primigeniu[s] / P(ubli) Ploti ∙>∙(centurionis) leg(ionis) / VII C(laudiae) P(iae) F(idelis) lib(ertus) an[n(orum)] / XX[---] h(ic) s(itus) e(st) / pat[ronus
column19: Inv. No. A 5054. Found in Kapljuč in secondary use as door to a tomb (likely).

column9: L(ucius) Riccius L(uci) f(ilius) Vel(ina) / Pessinunte ann(orum) LX vet(eranus) / Marcia Maxima uxor / L(ucius) Riccius L(uci) f(ilius) Valens / L(ucius) Riccius L(uci) f(ilius) Gallus / Riccia L(uci) [f(ilia)] Bulla / h(ic) s(iti) s(unt) / L(ucius) Atilius L(uci) f(ilius) Vel(ina) veter(anus) leg(ionis) VII / avunculo suo posuit et sibi
column19: It is very likely that this stelae includes reference to two soldiers of Legio VII (Lucius Atilius [definitely] and Lucius Riccius [likely]) for they are of the same family, tribe and likley of the same origin. Tončinic 2011, 82. EDCS also says Vid-Narona as location (likley based of BH Čitluk) with Tončinic 2011 claiming it is Čitluk Sinj (Aequum).

column5: Pre 1856, when it was first published
column9: T(itus) Sabinius T(iti) f(ilius) / Fab(ia) domo / Sebaste vete(ranus) / leg(ionis) VII ann(orum) LVI / sti(pendiorum) XXXII / h(ic) s(itus) e(st)
column19: Inv. No. A 32. Found in Salonitan North Necropolis on Porta Suburia Route I (Matinčevo), where, as Tončinić 2011 notes, MonumentID 8, 24, 95 were also found.

column9: D(is) M(anibus) / L(ucio) Septimio / Gratiano / mil(iti) leg(ionis) / VII Cl(audiae) exac/to co(n)s(ularis) v[i]/xit ann(os) XXII[II] / d(ies) XI Genia/lis Aug(usti) n(ostri) lib(ertus) / et Apuleia / Salvia filio / karissimo / pos(uerunt)
column19: INV. No. AMS-39549. Soldier was working under a legate in Dalmatia when the legio had moved to Viminacium. The dating is based on the name of his father (which dates to the Septimi) and the use of the reduced 'cpf' title - 'c(laudia)'.

column9: M(arcus) Sosius M(arci) f(ilius) / Fab(ia) Sebasto/[poli --- leg(ionis)] VII / [
column19: Inv. No. 97. Legio VII was possibly included on the original record of the inscription (1880) in the form of a 'VII', but the relevant line has since been lost. The Eastern origin of Marcus supports the argument for Legio VII however, as does the location of Humac, where other Legio VII monuments have been found. Monument is lost below second line of epitaph.

column5: Pre 1913, found during excavations led by Bulić
column9: M(arcus) Titius M(arci) f(ilius) S[er]/gia domo Isinda / eques leg(ionis) VII anno[r(um)] / XXXV stipend(iorum) X[---] / ex testament(o) fi[eri] / iussit arbitr[atu] / L(uci) Gelli M(arci) f(ilii) Serg[ia]
column19: Inv. No. A 4407. Found in Gradina, but may have been from East Necroplis at Salona. What is interesting here, is the presence of the doors, despite its nature as an altar (mult-dimensional monument).

column19: Inv. No. A 1073. Legio number is cut out, but VII is likley as a V is visible, and there is no space for a title in the lower line (thus not legio V macedonicae). Also, other monuments of legio VII were found nearby.

column9: [Dis Manibus] / sa[crum] / C(aius) Vibi[us) C(ai) f(ilius) Pompt(ina)] / Pedes [dom(o) Arret(io)] / >∙(centurio) leg(ionis) VI[I C(laudiae) P(iae) F(idelis) vivos fec(it)] / sibi et I[uliae C(ai) f(iliae) Pollae] / uxori
column19: Inv. No. 681. Found in field in church of st. Stephen (Trogir). The recorded inscription by Tončinić 2011 indicates that the inscription was cut off at Legio VI[I---, however, he agrees with the reconstruction of VI[I C(laudiae) p(iae) f(idelis)] with no indication as of why. It seems that Tončinić is not basing this off of the remaining monument (a fragment), instead the  CIL record which seems to have had more of the inscription as extant, see HD058437, so this is why he accepts the reconstruction. Because the line 'cpf' was visible when it was recorded in the CIL as a piece of Spolia from Trogir.

column5: May be first published in BD-VAHD (1) 1878 if the CIL entry is from one of the more 'recent' supplements (1880s, 90s, and 1900s)

No other monument from Bigests-Ljubuški has the cpf title, however, the space where the title may have been on this stelae is obscured, so one can not completely disregard the possibility (hence the date), Tončinić 2011 stresses this point.

column10: Gaius Julius, son of Gaius, of the Papiria tribe, born in Cormasa, discharged Legio VII cavalryman, set up this monument for himself and (his) freedman, Julius Iucundus.

column10: Here lies Gaius Aulius Secundus, son of Gaius, (registered in the voting tribe Aniensis, (from) the city of Cremona, veteran of legio VII Claudia pia fidelis. Arria Agathemeris made this for herself and her well-deserving husband, [and(?)] Quintus Arrius Priscus (?) [father or brother or patron]
column18: In secondary (tertiary?) use in modern house (Yippee)
column19: Now in secondary situ (in multiple pieces) inside a modern house. It was damaged during excvation, but is thought to have originally been in situ.

Tončinić 2011 dates it to beyond 42 CE but gives no evidence, and suggests it is a Legio VII member, but it may also be Legio V or VII, for findsite is unknown.

Tončinić 2011 suggests its origins in Eastern Necropolis, based off its the vicinity to the cemetery, and the number of Legio VII stele found there. Considered here as a funerary inscription, but could be a regular inscription.

column9: Severus Triocha/ri f(ilius) Ubius / eq(ues) ala(e) Tu/ngr(orum) ann(orum) / XXVI sti(pendiorum) V / h(ic) s(itus) e(st) Urban/us fratri pos(u)it
column19: Inv. No. A 5961. While this stela does not belong to a Legio VII legionary, it is included in this DB as an exemplum of how the stelae produced at Tilurium changed in style over time. Cambi 1994: e.g. One can see a reduction in the four pannels motif, with this stelae depicting two pannels

column9: C(aius) Iulius Bar/cenei f(ilius) The/odorus m/iles coh(ortis) II / Cyrrhesta/rum annor(um) / LXV stipen(diorum) XLII / h(ic) s(itus) e(st) posuit / C(aius) Iulius Scapula / frat(er)
column19: Inv. No. A 5962. While this stela does not belong to a Legio VII legionary, it is included in this DB as an exemplum of other military funerary stelae which would have been situated near or beside those of Legio VII members. It is also an example of a stela produced at the Tilurium workshop, in a different style to that typical of monuments belonging to Legio VII legionaries

column9: C(aius) Iulius An/dromachus / miles coh(ortis) II / Cyrr(h)estar(um) ann(orum) LXV stipend(iorum) / XXXX / C(aius) Iulius Apolla / sodalis vo(tum) posuit
column19: Inv. No. A 5963. While this stela does not belong to a Legio VII legionary, it is included in this DB as an exemplum of how the stelae produced at Tilurium changed in style over time. Cambi 1994: e.g. One can see a reduction in the four pannels motif, with this stelae depicting two pannels

column9: Γάϊοσ Παίνιοσ Νουμίσιοσ ἱππεὺσ οὐετπρανὸσ ληγεωνοσ ἑβδόμησ ἑαυτω καὶ τοῖσ ἰδίοισ
column10: Gaius Painius Numisius, veteran cavalryman of the seventh legion, set this up for himself and his descendants
column16: My own dates - could be 6-8 ending
column19: Included here because it is evidence of Legio VII's stay in Galatia prior to its arrival in Dalmatia in c.6-9 CE
